utterances: All right.
And the things he does to Jack Lemmon are just horrible.
Just horrible.
The character's name is Blake, by the way, and I'm with you.
I think he belongs on the list.
One person, one villain that almost nobody has mentioned, I don't think any of us has mentioned, is I talked about time, and this is the 70s-80s boss, and that's Gordon Gekko, Michael Douglas.
We did mention that, yes.
We did mention that?
Well, you know, greed is good.
It is, absolutely.
I'm learning it the hard way.
Michael, thanks very much for the call.
So next week, Murray, what are we going to talk about?
Next week we're going to talk about a genre that's one of my favorites.
It's movies about the movies.
So what's your favorite movie about the movie, or what's the movie that best captures something about the movies?
We're going to have more on this if you'd like to take a look at our website.
That's at npr.org.
Murray Horwitz of the Silver Theater here in the Washington, D.C., area.
We'll be back next week.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
Happy Thanksgiving.
Congressional Republicans are urging the Obama administration not to loosen sanctions on Iran during Obama's last two months in office.
That's because President-elect Donald Trump wants to renegotiate the nuclear deal with Iran.
NPR's Michele Kelemen reports on how Obama might still try to strengthen a deal that is central to his foreign policy legacy.
When the Treasury Department issued a license this week to the European consortium Airbus to sell planes to Iran, officials were quick to point out that this was in the pipeline for a while.
White House spokesman Josh Earnest says the U.S.
is just upholding its end of the bargain in a nuclear deal with Iran.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
The kinds of actions that we have taken in implementing the deal are the kinds of actions that have had to go through a rather extended process.
So I can confirm for you that I do not anticipate any actions being taken that were initiated after the election solely in response to Mr. Trump's victory.
He argues the deal is working and keeping Iran's nuclear program in check.
Critics say the White House has gone too far to help Iran reap the economic benefits of the deal.
House Speaker Paul Ryan and two other Republicans are calling on President Obama not to take any further action to bolster international investment in Iran.
Mark Dubowitz of the Foundation for the Defense of Democracies says the Trump transition officials now at the Treasury Department will also be on the lookout.

I expect the Trump transition team to be watching the Obama administration like a hawk and having certainly quiet conversations with administration officials signaling that a Trump administration won't countenance any unilateral action from the Obama administration in the waning days and weeks.
Besides, Dubowitz says, any further steps that look like concessions to Iran could backfire, playing into the hands of those who want to rip up the deal.

You know, the debate is going to take place between the 30-yard lines but to people who want to dismantle the deal on day one and those who believe that there is still an opportunity to enforce the deal aggressively and build strong leverage to negotiate a follow-on agreement.
So what could the Obama administration do?
A former Treasury Department official, Elizabeth Rosenberg, has this advice.

Strong outreach to Congress to make the case to those members of Congress certainly who supported the deal and possibly those who didn't support the deal but who recognize that it would be very damaging to undo it at this point.
Congress is expected to send to the White House soon legislation that would renew the current package of sanctions against Iran.
Rosenberg, who's now with the Center for a New American Security, says the Obama administration may not like it, but it could be worse.

They see it as unhelpful and unfriendly, but considering where Congress has been on sanctions towards Iran, this is a much more moderate approach than many of the pieces of legislation they have discussed and passed in the last couple of years that would have been much more hostile and that would have sought to directly, overtly break up the deal.
So how do we know this about back-to-back games contributing to injuries?
And again, I'm not saying this is all bad.
A lot of what he does is very, very good.
It's just I think the public ought to know that the CIA has been outsourcing a lot of this activity, which is very unusual.
It's sort of like John F.
Kennedy outsourcing the Bay of Pigs operation to the J.
Walter Thompson public relations and advertising company.

Half the CIA is now outsourced to private contractors, and it gets a lot of people very worried because these people aren't subject to a lot of the controls that normal CIA employees are subjected to and they don't come really under a lot of the congressional oversight, either.
Just to be clear about this, you're not accusing The Rendon Group of doing anything illegal.

It is not illegal to have public relations contracts or, indeed, to produce propaganda overseas, but you do write that that information gets back to this country and creates influence and opinion and ideas here.
Well, it can't help it.
When the Smith Act, which was the law that prohibits the government paying for propaganda in the US--when that was created, the times were much different.
Today, we have the Internet, we have instant communications.
There is no firewall between international media and domestic media these days.
But, no, in answer to your question, I'm not accusing The Rendon Group of violating any law.
I think that the public should know that there are these private contractors doing this type of work for the government.
You quote documents and statements from John Rendon and The Rendon Group to the effect that the company manages, in a very expert way, information.
They keep track of what is being written and printed and said and broadcast in foreign countries, and they do this in a very sophisticated way, and they're good at it.
Mr. Rendon says he is an information warrior, he also says that he's a patriot and the stories that come from The Rendon Group are true stories.
He deals only in the truth.

One of the very interesting things about how The Rendon Group operates and why it has a lot of contracts right now--it has--in the last four years, I think it's had--I've counted at least 35 contracts with the Pentagon and I don't now how many with the CIA.
But one of the things that it does now is it focuses on international media.

And what he prides himself on in the interview when he was talking to me was the fact that he can give policy-makers in the United States six hours' notice before a broadcast appears overseas to tell them what's going to be the lead story on the broadcast.

And he said that's very invaluable to a lot of the policy-makers because a lot of times, they'll want to have that six hours in order to prepare a rebuttal or do some fact-checking or come out with some opposition information.
James Bamford's article on The Rendon Group is in the December 1st issue of Rolling Stone.
Jim Bamford, thank you for coming in to speak with us on DAY TO DAY.
My pleasure, Alex.
And there's a link to that article--it's lengthy--at our Web site, npr.org.
This is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
The apple-picking season is drawing to a close, and in many places, farmers' markets are closing for the year.
But in Los Angeles, an effort to build a community around fruit--fruit that comes from other people's trees--is just starting to take hold.
DAY TO DAY producer Skye Rohde prepared this report.
Hola.
Hi.
Hi.
We were just admiring your apple trees.
You can have some apples.
Are you sure?
Is it OK?
Like many neighborhoods in Los Angeles, Silverlake is filled with fruit trees.
There's always something in season.
Avocados, lemons, limes and oranges are year-round; guavas, bananas, figs and passion fruit are seasonal.

Most people in Silverlake wouldn't think of walking into somebody's yard to pick fruit from their trees, but there's an unspoken rule that the fruit that hangs over a property boundary in the public space is up for grabs.
Three LA artists want to make this fruit a public good.
One of them, Dave Burns, is a college teacher.
This is about a resource, and the key word is `sharing.
So if there's a resource that's overlooked, and if it happens to be in your neighborhood, that--this is an opportunity to share.
It's not just share fruit--which is, of course, the theme--but it's actually to share resources and history and culture and knowledge and tradition and things like that.
LA's rich, but you mostly experience it through a car, so you don't know.
Burns and his fellow fruit lovers Austin Young and Matias Viegener mapped Silverlake and a few other LA neighborhoods and posted the maps on their Web site, fallenfruit.org.
This all started a year and a half ago as an art project.
Now the artists want to map fruit trees in neighborhoods across the nation with the help of a grant they just received.
There's a responsibility of due diligence, which is part about learning.
You know, we say, `Know your fruit,' so you want to learn your neighborhood and pay attention.
And then let's get real.
I mean, if you're going to go pick your neighborhood clean, that's hoarding, and that's not what we're about.
We're talking about walking down the street and grabbing an apple when it's overhanging the sidewalk.
The law is unclear as to whether it's legal to pick fruit off a tree planted on private property that leans over a sidewalk.
Los Angeles municipal law says it's legal to pick fruit from trees on city property, but the law is vague about the fruit on branches that hang over public property.
Los Angeles property lawyer Harry Gerrity says common sense may trump all else in a legal gray area like this.
If somebody asks me what to do--`Could I pick that fruit?'--I'd say, `Why don't you knock on the door of the person whose tree that belongs to and ask them if you can?'
Toni Ager(ph) agrees with that advice.
She lives in Hancock Park, an older, wealthier part of Los Angeles.
Her peach trees were listed in an article about fruit trees that hang over public property.
She says she and her husband are to happy to have people pick the ripe fruit.
For NPR News, I'm Curt Nickisch in Boston.
One woman who owns a building in Silverlake, Roxane Auer, even planted fruit trees on the edge of her property specifically so that people can have blood oranges and lemons when they want them.
When I finally got a chance to buy my first house, there's just this perfect big piece of dirt right out along the sidewalks.
And I really liked the idea of putting fruit trees there way out available to people to pick from, and even when the fruit came putting a sign up.
There's a fig.
Is that a fig?
